citation.article-title: Tateyamaria omphalii gen. nov., sp. nov., an alpha-Proteobacterium isolated from a top shell Omphalius pfeifferi pfeifferi.

p.s: Tateyamaria (Ta.te.ya.ma’ri.a. L. fem. suff. – aria belonging to; N.L. fem. n. Tateyamaria belonging to Tateyama City, the origin of the animal from which the organism was isolated).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile coccoid to short rods.
Neither flagella nor endospores are observed.
Beige colonies on marine agar medium are circular, convex, smooth, and shiny.
On marine agar, the strain develops colonies within 2–3 d, and the colonies grow aerobically but not anaerobically.
In media devoid of sodium chloride, no growth is observed.
The predominant respiratory quinone present is ubiquinone 10 (Q10).
The cellular fatty acids comprise 18:1ω7c, 16:0, 11 methyl 18:1ω7c, cyclo 19:0ω8c, 3-OH 10:0, and 3-OH 12:0.
Phylogenetically, the genus forms a distinct clade within α-Proteobacteria and contains one species, T. omphalii.
The type species of the genus is T. omphalii.
